mechanism_of_action: Paracetamol selectively inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-2 and COX-3) enzymes in the central nervous system, reducing prostaglandin synthesis responsible for pain and fever. It exhibits minimal peripheral anti-inflammatory activity compared to NSAIDs. Additional mechanisms include activation of descending inhibitory serotonergic pathways and cannabinoid receptor modulation, supported by strong preclinical evidence and clinical trials.

pharmacokinetics.absorption: Paracetamol is rapidly absorbed from the small intestine with bioavailability of 70-90% due to first-pass hepatic metabolism. Peak plasma levels occur 0.5-2 hours post-oral dose; intravenous administration achieves 100% bioavailability instantly. Food, particularly high-fat meals, may delay absorption by 0.5-1 hour without altering extent.
pharmacokinetics.metabolism: Hepatic metabolism predominates: 50-60% glucuronidation, 25-35% sulfation, 5-10% CYP2E1-mediated oxidation to NAPQI (detoxified by glutathione). Minor pathways involve CYP1A2 and CYP3A4. Chronic alcohol use induces CYP2E1, increasing NAPQI production.
pharmacokinetics.elimination: Primarily renal excretion of metabolites (glucuronide 55%, sulfate 30%, cysteine/mercapturic acid 10%); <5% unchanged drug. Clearance is 300-500 mL/min in adults; reduced in renal impairment (CrCl <30 mL/min). Dialyzable in overdose.
pharmacokinetics.half_life: 1-4 hours (mean 2-3 hours) in healthy adults; prolonged to 5-8 hours in hepatic impairment, neonates, or malnutrition. Therapeutic range monitoring uses Rumack-Matthew nomogram in overdose.

off_label_uses: Patent ductus arteriosus closure in neonates (strong evidence)
clinical_use.standard_dosing: Adults: 500-1000 mg orally/IV/rectally every 4-6 hours PRN; maximum 4000 mg/24 hours. Children >12 years: same as adults; 2-12 years: 10-15 mg/kg/dose every 4-6 hours, max 75 mg/kg/day. Neonates: 10-15 mg/kg every 6-8 hours.

dose_adjustments.Renal impairment (CrCl 10-50 mL/min): Every 6 hours; CrCl <10 mL/min: every 8 hours
dose_adjustments.Malnutrition/obesity: Use ideal body weight for dosing

contraindications.Hypersensitivity to paracetamol: Risk of anaphylaxis or severe skin reactions; absolute.

contraindications.G6PD deficiency: Limited evidence for hemolytic risk; avoid high doses.

black_box_warnings: Severe liver injury may occur with therapeutic doses exceeding 4000 mg/day or lower in risk factors (alcohol, malnutrition); check total daily dose from all sources.
Overdosage (>7.5-10 g acute) risks fulminant hepatic failure requiring transplant; antidotal therapy with N-acetylcysteine within 8-24 hours critical.
Risk increased 3-4 fold with chronic alcohol use (>3 drinks/day).

drug_interactions.mechanism: Paracetamol inhibits warfarin metabolism (CYP2C9) and displaces from albumin.
drug_interactions.management: Monitor INR frequently; limit paracetamol to <2000 mg/day.

drug_interactions.mechanism: Alcohol induces CYP2E1, increasing NAPQI formation; depletes glutathione.

drug_interactions.management: Monitor efficacy; may need dose increase.
No adjustment needed; monitor for efficacy.

food_interactions.clinical_effect: Tmax delayed 0.5-1 hour; no change in AUC.
food_interactions.management: Administer 30 min before meals if rapid onset needed.
Avoid concurrent use; separate by >6 hours if unavoidable.

environmental_considerations: Store at <25°C in tight container; protect from moisture/light.
Avoid freezing oral liquids; shake suspensions well.
Not for use in extreme heat/humidity without stability data.

what_to_do.action: Assess total daily paracetamol intake from all sources (e.g., combination products).
what_to_do.rationale: Prevents inadvertent overdose; multi-source use causes 30-50% of hepatotoxicity cases.

what_to_do.action: Administer N-acetylcysteine (NAC) for overdose if >150 mg/kg or symptoms within 24 hours.
what_to_do.rationale: Replenishes glutathione; survival >95% if <8 hours post-ingestion.
what_to_do.monitoring: Paracetamol level at 4 hours; LFTs q12h.

what_to_do.action: Limit chronic use to <3 g/day in elderly/hepatic risk patients.
what_to_do.rationale: Prolonged half-life increases accumulation; RCTs show safety up to 3 g/day.

what_not_to_do.action: Do not exceed 4000 mg/day total from all formulations.
what_not_to_do.risks: Dose-dependent hepatotoxicity; 6 g/day doubles ALT elevation risk.
what_not_to_do.safer_alternatives: Alternate with ibuprofen if no contraindications; non-pharmacologic (ice/heat).
Abstinence or opioid alternatives under supervision.

what_not_to_do.action: Do not use extended-release with immediate-release concurrently.

debunked_claims.claim: Paracetamol is safe with moderate alcohol (1-2 drinks/day).
debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Induces CYP2E1 even with moderate intake per pharmacokinetic studies.

debunked_claims.claim: Paracetamol cures the common cold or flu.
debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Symptomatic relief only; no antiviral activity per RCTs.

requirements: Liver function tests (ALT/AST) baseline and every 2-4 weeks for chronic use (>14 days).
Serum paracetamol concentration 4 hours post-ingestion in suspected overdose.
Renal function (SCr) in chronic high-dose use.
